ygData.subject: Re: New paper investigating HyperNEAT's sensitivity to different geometric repre

Subject: Re: New paper investigating HyperNEAT's sensitivity to different geometric repre
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=hvkW9xQgVT8MksaaX4PcDpD2U3xtr2l-I7mgM6D28yDp9JCO6T1F

Peter, Jeff and I have had a lot of in-depth conversations about whether or=
 not the good performance of randomized geometry has anything to do with it=
s geometry at all or whether it's just the indirect encoding.  

As I've sa=
id to Jeff, I believe that anything HyperNEAT does has something to do with=
 geometry so the connection is inescapable.  While it is an indirect encodi=
ng, the encoding itself is a function of geometry, so it cannot be consider=
ed independently of that geometry.  

My hypothesis, which I've discussed w=
ith Jeff, is that in some domains almost *any* random layout has some kind =
of exploitable geometric relationship.  It may not be the most convenient o=
ne, but it is still better than nothing.  Of course, having a "good" geomet=
ry is better than a random one (as Jeff also shows), but I still think a ra=
ndom one probably has some useful relationships on average (at least in the=
 quadruped domain).

The question for me is whether HyperNEAT can succeed w=
ith random geometries in general, or just in particular domains.  It clearl=
y can do it in the quadruped domain, but I wonder about others.  Perhaps th=
e quadruped has properties that make the geometry more forgiving than in mo=
st domains.  

However, you (Peter) note that you also saw the same thing i=
n your own experiments.  So maybe it's a somewhat widespread phenomenon.

I=
 think that what is important is not so much that you can randomize geometr=
y, because there isn't really much reason you'd want it to be completely ra=
ndom, but that it shows that you don't need to get it perfect to still do w=
ell.  That is definitely good news.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "pet=
ar_chervenski" <petar_chervenski@...> wrote:
>
> Hi!
> 
> Thanks for postin=
g this paper, great work!
> By the way I also noticed that HyperNEAT perfor=
ms well even in cases of a substrate that is messed up. My first release of=
 the NEVH experiment had a bug, it was not symmetrical and basically it cou=
ld be considered randomized. Yet it was still able to evolve good behaviors=
, though. I wonder, is this linked to the geometry at all? Perhaps only the=
 fact that this indirect encoding searches trough less dimensions, makes it=
 more effective?
> 
> Peter
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stan=
ley" <kstanley@> wrote:
> >
> > Just for the record, I highly recommend thi=
s paper.  It's the most extensive study published on the effect of varying =
geometry on HyperNEAT performance.  Some of its results are quite interesti=
ng.  
> > 
> > For example, it suggests that HyperNEAT is still significant=
ly better than a direct encoding encoding even if its geometry is randomize=
d! (Although it is still worse than an engineered geometry.)  Jeff and I ha=
ve discussed how to interpret this result and my own opinion is that most r=
andomized geometries nevertheless still have some useful geometry, and some=
thing is better than nothing.  So it suggests that you don't have to necess=
arily hit on the "perfect" substrate geometry to get traction out of HyperN=
EAT.
> > 
> > Yet I think a big question that emerges from this result is w=
hether it is somehow tied specifically to the quadruped domain.  It is poss=
ible that it has something to with the fact that a quadruped can get along =
pretty well if all its legs move in tandem, so you have the opportunity to =
represent that repetition regardless of how the legs are organized geometri=
cally.  It is possible that other types of systems are less geometrically f=
orgiving, though that remains to be seen.
> > 
> > Of course, in practice, =
if the right geometry is even partially clear, the resultant informed subst=
rate configuration is probably going to be better than a random geometry.  =
The "engineered" geometries (meaning they are designed by a human to make s=
ense) still outperform the random ones in the paper, even as the random one=
s outperform the direct encoding.
> > 
> > Anyway, in my view, the most imp=
ortant implication is that geometry matters.  If you can construct a sensib=
le geometry, HyperNEAT will indeed take advantage of it to learn the task. =
 And even if it's not perfect, it's better than having no geometric knowled=
ge at all.
> > 
> > ken
> > 
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <j=
clune@> wrote:
> > >
> > > Hello all-
> > > 
> > > Below is a link to a new=
 HyperNEAT paper that I will present at GECCO 2009
> > > this summer. It st=
udies how sensitive HyperNEAT is to different geometric
> > > representatio=
ns of the same problem.
> > > 
> > > I am especially excited about this pap=
er because it was nominated for the
> > > Best Paper Award in the Generativ=
e and Developmental Systems track. If you
> > > are going to GECCO this yea=
r, and enjoyed the paper, please keep it in mind
> > > when casting your ba=
llot.
> > > 
> > > The paper can be viewed here:
> > > 
> > > https://www.m=
su.edu/~jclune/webfiles/publications/Clune-HyperNEATSensitivity
> > > ToGeo=
metry.pdf
> > > 
> > > Abstract:
> > > 
> > > HyperNEAT, a generative encod=
ing for evolving artificial neural networks
> > > (ANNs), has the unique an=
d powerful ability to exploit the geometry of a
> > > problem (e.g., symmet=
ries) by encoding ANNs as a function of a problem's
> > > geometry. This pa=
per provides the first extensive analysis of the
> > > sensitivity of Hyper=
NEAT to different geometric representations of a
> > > problem. Understandi=
ng how geometric representations affect the quality of
> > > evolved soluti=
ons should improve future designs of such representations.
> > > HyperNEAT =
has been shown to produce coordinated gaits for a simulated
> > > quadruped=
 robot with a specific two-dimensional geometric representation.
> > > Here=
, the same problem domain is tested, but with different geometric
> > > rep=
resentations of the problem. Overall, experiments show that the quality
> >=
 > and kind of solutions produced by HyperNEAT can be substantially affecte=
d by
> > > the geometric representation. HyperNEAT outperforms a direct enc=
oding
> > > control even with randomized geometric representations, but per=
forms even
> > > better when a human engineer designs a representation that=
 reflects the
> > > actual geometry of the robot. Unfortunately, even choic=
es in geometric
> > > layout that seem to be inconsequential a priori can s=
ignificantly affect
> > > fitness. Additionally, a geometric representation=
 can bias the type of
> > > solutions generated (e.g., make left-right symm=
etry more common than
> > > front-back symmetry). The results suggest that =
HyperNEAT practitioners can
> > > obtain good results even if they do not k=
now how to geometrically represent
> > > a problem, and that further improv=
ements are possible with a well-chosen
> > > geometric representation.
> > =
> 
> > > 
> > > 
> > > As always, I look forward to any questions or commen=
ts you may have.
> > > 
> > > Cheers,
> > > Jeff Clune
> > > 
> > > Digital=
 Evolution Lab, Michigan State University
> > > 
> > > jclune@
> > >
> >
>
